message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest the patient is suffering from Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) and antiretroviral therapy should be initiated along with antibiotics. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is used to treat PCP and also prevents Toxoplasmosis, another opportunistic infection that occurs with low CD4+ T-lymphocyte counts. Candidiasis, Cryptosporidiosis, and Cytomegalovirus end-organ disease are not prevented by TMP-SMX.

The symptoms and presence of disc-shaped yeast cells in the bronchoalveolar lavage suggest pneumocystis pneumonia, a common opportunistic infection in patients with HIV. The treatment for this is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. This also prevents toxoplasmosis, a parasitic infection that often affects the brain in immunocompromised patients. Candidiasis is a fungal infection that can be prevented with antifungal agents. Cryptosporidiosis is a parasitic infection that can be prevented with proper hygiene measures. Cytomegalovirus end-organ disease is a serious complication of HIV but is prevented with antiviral medications, not trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
